column1: `flwr.client.NumPyClient` is a convenience class built on top of `flwr.client.Client`. The difference is that `Client` sends/receives lower-level values that are close to the actual gRPC messages sent over the wire
column2: which in turn means that you have to write a bit more boilerplate code when implementing it. `NumPyClient` is more opinionated (which also means less flexible)
column3: but it does a lot of this boilerplate work for you in return.

column1: One example for this boilerplate work is the conversion of model parameters. On the gRPC level
column2: Flower communicates model parameters as byte arrays. To be more precise

column1: `repeated` is ProtoBuf-syntax for a list/array-ish data structure. So `Parameters` is a list of byte arrays and a string `tensor_type` that tells someone receiving a `Parameters` object how those byte arrays should be interpreted (after all
column2: the byte arrays could contain anything). The Flower code examples usually serialize a single neural network layer into a byte arrays
column4: the `Parameters` object should have a list `tensors` with as many entries as the model has layers.

column1: Since the transport layer uses byte arrays
column2: we have to convert *whatever* model parameters we have into byte arrays. `NumPyClient` is the convenience class that does it for you by asking you to use a list of NumPy `ndarray` objects. So when you return from `fit`
column3: you take the PyTorch `state_dict` and turn it into a list of NumPy `ndarray`s. `NumPyClient` then does a second conversion from this list into a list of byte arrays.

column2: the reverse happens: we receive the `Parameters` object with the list of byte arrays
column3: but then we have de-serialize it into a list of NumPy `ndarray`s before we can do any computation on it. This is done inside the `aggregate_fit` method: it converts `Parameters` to `ndarray`s

column4: one can absolutely save the aggregated parameters as a PyTorch `state_dict`. `aggregate_fit` returns a `Parameters` object that has to be transformed into a list of NumPy `ndarray`s
